awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Structure and Influence of Coherent Vertical Pulses of Wave Activity Flux in Observations and Models, from Daily to Seasonal Timescales
awd_abstract_narration:
The stratosphere, an atmospheric layer about 8-10 km above the surface, can influence winter weather over the Northern Hemisphere via its interactions with the troposphere beneath.  These interactions can take several weeks to develop and mature, and may provide information about changes to weather patterns two to six weeks in advance, particularly during the fall and winter.  An important starting point for some of these interactions is a change in the tropospheric winds over Northern Eurasia that occurs over a relatively short period, generally less than two weeks.  This change in winds is associated with the "vertical pulses of wave activity flux", which can influence the polar stratosphere and, eventually, surface weather.  This research aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of these short-term "pulse events" and their hemispheric influence by examining the spatial structure and temporal evolution of the events and investigating their role in the initiation of slower troposphere-stratosphere interactions that end up resulting in changes to weather over regions remote from the pulses, including over parts of North America, Europe, and Asia. This improved understanding will also provide an evaluation of the potential for considering these pulse events in the prediction of some aspects of weather variability up to several weeks in advance.  The events will be studied using observational data for examining their structure and investigating their underlying physical mechanisms, and also using the output of weather forecast models to assess how realistically models are able to reproduce these events and their influence.
 
This investigation will provide a better understanding of how the troposphere and stratosphere interact and of one of the causes of variations in winter weather.  The project will also educate and train graduate students and include public outreach and education through development of a teaching portal, student presentation of tutorials through social media, and provision of an experimental forecast.

por.por_cntn:
The troposphere is the lowest layer of the atmosphere, extending from the surface up to about 15 km (roughly 9 miles).  The stratosphere is the next layer up, extending from about 15 km to 50 km (9 miles to 30 miles). The stratosphere usually varies in response to the troposphere but sometimes the stratosphere can also have an important influence on the troposphere, including on winter weather over the United States. Understanding how the troposphere and stratosphere can influence each other ("troposphere-stratosphere interactions") is an important area of study, both for improving our understanding of how the atmosphere works in the current and warming climate, and for the potential to forecast some episodes of high-impact weather with longer lead times than are currently reliable.

One of the main ways that the troposphere influences the stratosphere is through the action of very large waves in the atmosphere, hundreds to thousands of miles in horizontal extent, called "Rossby Waves."  While these waves are perhaps most familiar as the north-south undulations in the jet stream on a weather map, they can also move vertically from the surface high up through the stratosphere, like ripples moving away from a rock thrown into a pond. The focus of this project was to analyze how the troposphere influences the stratosphere during periods when these waves are very actively moving upward from just a few locations at the surface over a relative short period of time, around ten days or so.  Because the wave activity in these cases is concentrated in both space and time and moving vertically, we refer to these events as upward wave pulses. In the project, we showed that there are three main locations in the Northern Hemisphere that contribute strongly to upward wave pulses. While the upward wave activity in each location appears to be generally independent from the activity in the other locations, during times when there does happen to be activity in all three locations within a roughly two-week period, the response in the stratosphere is much larger than the sum of the responses when the activity occurs in the regions individually. In fact, these combined pulses can lead to very large disruptions of the usual conditions in the stratosphere, called "Sudden Stratospheric Warmings," when the stratosphere warms dramatically and the main circulation feature, the Stratospheric Polar Vortex, becomes very weak. We applied Machine Learning (ML) techniques to identify regularly-occurring circulation patterns in the stratosphere, including different strengths of the polar vortex, which we used to show that the wave pulses are, on average, followed by a notable weaking of the polar vortex.

During the final year of the project, a Sudden Stratospheric warming occurred in January 2021, followed by a severe cold air outbreak over the south-central United States in February 2021, resulting in more than 250 deaths and damage estimated at more than 20 billion dollars. According to NOAA, it was the most-costly winter storm event on record for the United States.  Using the analysis techniques and perspective of the project, we were able to contribute to an analysis linking the cold air outbreak to the vertical movement of waves between the troposphere and stratosphere, and also to link that vertical movement back to surface changes over the Arctic during the preceding fall, associated with climate change. The attached figure shows a schematic of this pathway of influence.

There are two key aspects to the scientific merit of the project results.  The analysis of wave pulses and circulation patterns has provided a better understanding of how the troposphere affects the stratosphere, in terms of the importance of wave activity associated with specific locations and the interactions between the activity in the different locations.  Additionally, the results have also shown how the stratosphere can provide a pathway for Arctic climate change in the fall to influence severe winter weather over the United States in the following winter. 

Finally, there is broader impact and important societal relevance to both main scientific results, in terms of identifying the potential for better forecasts based on the wave pulses and circulation patterns identified here, as well in showing that high impact winter weather can still occur - and, in some circumstances, is enhanced - in a warming climate.
